column8: Source

column9:
The first temperature and wind observations made in the Malayan peninsula were by officers of the British East India Company. They left no record of rainfall, probably because they were using measuring instruments from their ships, which did not carry rain gauges. The EIC had an interest in studying the local weather to explore the viability of making a permanent settlement. After a settlement was established, doctors quickly took an interest in making weather observations, concerned about the 'healthiness' of the region for European colonisation and linking good weather with good health (Ward, 1830).
(Click on the location balloons for each year to find out more!)

column7: In Singapore, the first coherent weather records we have were made under the governorship of William Farquhar at Government Hill. In some accounts, the EEIC Bengal Native Infantry officer Charles Edward Davies is credited with making the Singapore readings.
column8:
Charles Edward Davis
Farquhar, W. (1827). Thermometrical and barometrical tables (pp. 585–586). Transactions of the Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain and Ireland. (Call no.: RRARE 551.609595 FAR; Accession no.: B29032746K)
Malayan Meteorological Service. (1950). Annual report of the Malayan Meteorological Service, 1949 (p. 5).

column9: During the 1830s, local weather observations were printed for the public in the local press, though we are not sure by whom they were made or for what purpose. A clue from the Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser (5 March 1840) suggests that they may have been made by an interested amateur, rather than as part of military or medical research.

column7: One such amateur was an American missionary, Joseph S. Travelli. He recorded Singapore's temperature and rainfall from the mission school where he worked, run by the American Board of Foreign Missions located at Ryan's Hill (now Bukit Pasoh).

Located along Kallang River, Elliot's observatory was described as small but well designed for making weather observations. Direct sunlight was prevented from reaching the meteorological instruments and the walls were 18 inches thick and painted white in order to reflect heat (Elliot, 1849).
The observatory was closed in 1845 due to the withdrawal of funds from London. The instruments were sent to India for re-use in the observatory in Bombay.
column8: C. M. Elliot, Singapore Magnetic Observatory Yearbook
column9: In the 1840s, a fantastic experiment took place. Guided by the British Association for the Advancement of Science (BAAS) and the Royal Society in London, a formal observatory was established in Singapore. Run by Lieutenant Charles Elliot, an EEIC officer, it was Singapore's first semi-permanent research station to investigate magnetism, astronomy and weather. The observatory was located along Kallang River.

column8: J. S. Travelli (1843), American Journal Arts and of Science

column9: After the observatory closed in 1845 and until the early 1860s, we don't know if any weather observations were still being made in Singapore.  But they had resumed by 1864.

column7:
In the mid-1860s we start to see weather records appear again, some made by professionals and some by semi-amateurs. Plantation owner Jonas Daniel Vaughan was the first and one of the most comprehensive observers of this period. In his early life, he had served in the Bengal Marines, before being posted to Singapore as Master Attendant and Marine Magistrate in 1856 (Gibson, 1960; Makepeace, 1921). After retirement, he started a plantation in the River Valley Road area (then known as the Killeny Estate) alongside his police duties.
His observations (1863-6) were published in the Straits Settlements Government Gazette.

Arthur Knight, Vaughan's neighbour, also made meteorological observations at his estate at Mount Pleasant in Toa Payoh (Irvine Rowell, 1885). This would have been an incredible long series of observations spanning 17 years if all the information survived. Unfortunately, only the 1864-1869 data can be found.
column8: A. Knight, in Wheatley (1881), Journal of the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society

column7: As we can see during the 1870s, most of the weather records were made by local agriculturalists and landowners. The only official observations we know of were made at Singapore's Raffles and Horsburgh lighthouses during 1864 to 1867 by Thomas Todd (senior keeper) and J. W. Flory (second keeper) respectively (e.g. Todd, 1864). This series was short but far more detailed than those made by the amateur weather-watchers. Their bbservations included pressure, temperature, wind and rainfall and were made 3 times daily at sunrise, noon and sunset.

Horsburgh was the first lighthouse to be built through British funding in Singapore. Opened in 1850, it was named after Captain James Horsburgh, a hydrographer to the EEIC from 1810 to 1836. The Raffles lighthouse opened four years after Horsburgh and is still in operation today.
The lighthouse records were originally published in the Government Gazette however, they ceased to be published after 1867 although they were most likely still made. We do not know where these original records are today.

column9:
In 1869, meteorology for the Straits Settlements was brought under the control of the Medical Department for historic and practical reasons. Firstly, the interest in medical meteorology, a field of medical research that based its investigations on connections between health and weather, grew in the 19th century. As the century progressed, a quantitative method of comparing diseases incidence with meteorological data became common across the colonies of the British Empire (e.g. Walker, 1876, 1925). Secondly, the medical department also offered a coherent infrastructure for the systematic collation of observations within a controlled environment.

The annual average from the Government Gazette is for the whole of Singapore.

column5: H.L. Randall, Colonial Surgeon (and A.F. Anderson, Acting Pricinpal Civil Medical Officer Aug 1827 - Jun 1873)
column6: Temperature recorded was 26.97°C for the whole of Singapore.
column7:
The first official set of observations under the medical department were made in Singapore at the Convict Jail (Bras Basah) Hospital between 1869 and 1874. This hospital was originally intended to hold transported prisoners (mainly of Indian origin) from other British colonies. The weather data is very detailed and standardised, observations made 3 times a day.
Despite the detailed records, little in known about the small-scale observatory or who made the records. The prison itself was designed and established by George Coleman, Superintendent of Public Works and of Convicts. There was an open plan area with numerous workshops and studio, one of which was presumably an observatory space (McNair & Bayliss, 1889).
Coleman handed operations to his successor, Major John Fedrick McNair, also a prominent architect and engineer. McNair may have supervised a subordinate or even a trusted prisoner to make the observations but they were ultimately signed off by the Colonial Surgeon, H.L. Randall. In 1867, the practice of transporting prisoners ended and six years later, so did the observations from this hospital.
column8:
Principal Civil Medical Officer (P.C.M.O) of the Medical Department, Government Gazette and The Straits Times

column7: The newly gathered long-term weather data led Principal Chief Medical Officer H.L. Randall to conclude that the amount of rainfall affected the numbers of cases of cholera, arguing that "to a great extent, the health of Singapore is dependent on its Rainfall".

column7: The practice of making observations at plantations also continued. Into the early 1870s for example, Alsagoff and Company, who owned lemongrass plantations in Peserverance Estate (now Geylang area), made records for rainfall that were published in the Straits Settlements Government Gazette, 1875). The family run business was headed by Syed Osmar bin Mohamed Alsagoff who was a leading member of the local Muslim community and one of the largest plantation owners in Singapore (Tan, 2009).

column7: After the Convict Jail was closed down, Kandang Kerbau Hospital took over the meteorological role, making observations in a dedicated observatory. KKH grew to become the largest medical facility in Singapore (Lee, 1990). The dataset is very detailed and standardised. Although we do not know exactly who made the observations, there were references made to the Assistant Surgeons and apothcaries working at the hospital undertaking the role (e.g. Government Gazette, 1892).

column9: Under the medical department, the number of observation stations across Singapore grew in this period. This expansion had much to do with the enthusiasm of Principal Chief Medical Officer T. Irvine Rowell, who served as PCMO from 1877. His interest in meteorology spanned beyond the practice of medicine. He studied how patterns of settlement might have impacted local weather, especially the purported connection between deforestation and rainfall, as he was interested in understanding anthropogenic changes in climate. Under him, the number of weather stations would rise to around 29  including one at the General Hospital, Sepoy Lines and Waterworks Reservoir (MacRitchie Reservoir).

column7: MacRitchie reservoir opened at the very end of 1877 and rainfall records were made there from the following year. This dataset comprises one of Singapore's longest, as records are still kept there today. The only gap was during the Second World War.
column8: MacRitchie Reservoir Monthly Rainfall, 1879 - 1948

column9: During the 1890s, there seems to have been a decrease in the number of weather stations. This may be due to records being lost. These two locations we found only provided rainfall data but none for temperatures.

column7:
In September 1903, it was suggested by R. S. Fry, who ran a small observatory with a timeball for ships on Pulau Brani, that the facility ought to be moved to Mount Faber because the accuracy of the clock was being impaired by nearby reclamation works. His advice was taken and the observatory on Mount Faber began operation on 1 June 1905.
In 1929, the Faber Observatory was expanded to become the first full-scale observation station in Singapore. Singapore was also made the headquarters of the Malayan Meteorological Service with its offices located in the Fullerton Building (now hotel).
column8: Makepeace, W., Brooke, G. E., & Braddell, R. St. J. (Eds.). (1991). One hundred years of Singapore (Vol. 1). Singapore: Oxford University Press, p. 481. (Call no.: RSING 959.57 ONE-[HIS]); Ng, M. F. C. (2012). A ride to remember: The story of Mount Faber and Singapore Cable Car. Singapore: Mount Faber Leisure Group, p. 12. Available via PublicationSG.

column9: In 1934, the Mount Faber station as well as the headquarters at the Fullerton Building were moved to Kallang Airport, which the authorities thought was a more suitable location for observing Singapore’s weather and for the transmission of weather information to aircraft.

column8: Survey Department. (1932). Survey Department, Straits Settlements. In Annual Departmental Reports of the Straits Settlements for the year 1931 (p. 18). Singapore: Government Printing Press. (Call no.: RRARE 325.3410959 SSADRS; Microfilm no.: NL2921)

column9:
The Kandang Kerbau observations were not published in the government gazettes beyond 1917 although they continued to be made. A possible explanation for their public disappearance was that the meteorology was moved out of the Medical Department and into the Museum Department under Herbert Robinson.
After this, all meteorological returns for the peninsula were collated by specialist clerks in the employ of the Museum’s Department (SEL: SEC 1108/1925). This was the preamble to the establishment of a formal, dedicated Malayan Meteorological Department in 1929 (Maxwell & Robinson, 1927)

column6: Temperature recorded was 27.0°C for the whole of Singapore.

column6: Temperature recorded was 27.0°C for the whole of Singapore.

column9: Before Singapore gained independence in 1965, weather records were kept by the Malayan Meteorological Services. Their main observation station was in Paya Lebar and they had 30 auxiliary stations, some in Singapore (such as Tengah, Seletar, Mandai and Jurong East) and others in Malaya. After 1965, the Meteorological Service Singapore (MSS) was formed. In 1970, the storm warning radar at Paya Lebar was replaced with one that could track and locate storms up to 400km away. This provided the airport with more accurate details for aircraft landing (The Straits Times, 14 December 1965; The Straits Times, 17 April 1970).

column6: Temperature recorded was 26.9°C for the whole of Singapore.
Temperature recorded was 26.9°C for the whole of Singapore.
column7:
The weather station at Paya Lebar Airport was built in the late 1950s.
A photograph of Yang di-Pertuan Negara Yusof Ishak peering into a weather apparatus at Paya Lebar Airport can be found in the Yusof Ishak Collection, in courtesy of National Archives of Singapore (https://biblioasia.nlb.gov.sg/vol-16/issue-2/jul-sep-2020/rain#fnref:10)
column8: https://biblioasia.nlb.gov.sg/vol-16/issue-2/jul-sep-2020/rain#fnref:10

column9: In the 1990s, there were 25 weather stations in Singapore, though only a handful provided temperature data. Perhaps due to the large number of floods happening in Singapore post-independence, the focus became to monitor rainfall levels. It is not clear if temperature observations were made and lost,  not made at all, or whether all  records were merged into other kinds of data.

In the 2000s, the number of weather stations keeping records of temperature increased. These records mainly consist of the daily maximum and minimum temperature as well as the daily average.
The image shows an isotherm map for the year 2000 produced using the average temperature data of the weather stations. An isotherm map gives a visual representation of the distribution of the surface temperature across a defined location. The more data points acquired, the more accurate the map will be.
From the isotherm map we can see that in 2000, the eastern region of Singapore was warmer than the west. This could be attributed to rapid development of this region, and downtown, producing an Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect (Concept Plan, 1991).

By 2010, there are 58 weather stations in Singapore. Only those that recorded temperature data are shown in this map. We can observe a general increase in the surface temperature across Singapore since 2000, regardless of the region. Population increased from 4.02 million to 5.07 million in just 10 years (2000-2010). More infrastructure such as transport and buildings (for housing and business) was also in place. Following the 2001 Concept Plan, the urban center in downtown was decentralised to the western region, and new buildings were still being built in mature estates such as Queenstown and Redhill but with more density and at greater heights (URA, 2001). Development partly resulted in higher temperatures being recorded in the east, west and north regions of Singapore due to the UHI effect.
The 2001 Concept Plan also draw a focus to greening Singapore. Green spaces such as the Central Catchment Area were left untouched and there were plans to increase Singapore's green spaces from 2,500 ha to 4,500 ha. As such we can see a region of cooler surface temperature in Singapore's central region.

column6: Weather station only started operating in February 2010. There was no temperature data, only rainfall data.
Weather station only started operating in March 2010. There was no temperature data, only rainfall data

column9: Despite measures to increase green spaces, the rate of urban development outweighed the cooling effect made by greening Singapore. The Central Business District (CBD) of Singapore in the southeastern region, Jurong (western region) and Jurong Islands (Singapore's offshore island in the west) reflected areas of higher temperature compared to the rest of the city. Decentralising the urban centre from the CBD area to Jurong may have helped reduce temperature increase in the southeast region of Singapore, but led to pockets of higher heat in the west. Jurong Island, being a heavily industrialised area, was not spared the experience of higher heat despite being surrounded by water.

From the graph below, we can see that Singapore's average and minimum temperatures have increased by around 2℃ from the beginning of our record-keeping. The rapid increase in population resulting in the need for greater hard infrastructure has contributed through the Urban Heat Island effect to the overall temperature rise. Urban planning has thus played a major role in shaping the urban thermal environment, including setting aside green spaces to keep some areas of Singapore cooler.
Nonetheless, as the earth continues to warm, the extent and intensity of urban heat in Singapore will be further amplified. This will not only affect the liveability of Singapore, it will also create health issues. Singapore will need to develop even more effective ways to mitigate heat, as time is running out.
